html:
LONDON, December 10 (IFR)

  • Qiagen to refinance paper with 2027 CBs 
  • Mithra raises €125m from five-year CB 
  • Electrocomponents raises £180m for acquisitions 
  • Aveva reports 99.1% take-up on £2.84bn rights issue 
  • NKT rights issue gets 99.5% take-up
  • Fugro reports 91.9% rights issue take-up
  • Implats buys back 7.4% of 6.375% 2022 paper
  • Ecofin US Renewables Fund needs more time
  • JP Morgan Global Core Real Assets extends
  • Downing Renewables fund steady on debut

La Verdosa is selling 2.1m shares in Spanish renewable energy business Acciona on Thursday evening, representing 3.8% of share capital and launched with guidance of €105-€107 versus the €113 close. On guidance, the deal size will be €220.5m-€225m. Credit Suisse is bookrunner.

Dutch biotech services group Qiagen launched a US$500m seven-year convertible bond on Thursday, with proceeds to finance a tender for its US$177.2m 0.875% 2021 convertible bonds as well as for general corporate purposes.

The tender wrapped up on Thursday afternoon with pricing on the new issue still awaited as IFR went to press.  

Launched at US$450m, the zero-coupon CB was offered at 100%–102% of principal for a yield-to-maturity of negative 0.28% to zero. The premium was to be set at 45%–55% over the two day VWAP on the NYSE for Thursday and Friday.

The bonds can be called from five years subject to a 130% hurdle.

The tender was for non-US holders of the 2021 CBs and ran concurrently on Thursday, closing at 4:30pm in London.

Books were covered on the new issuance before 9am and shortly before 11am investors were advised that the deal had been upsized to US$500m and orders not at 55% premium and 100% risked missing out, with books due to close at 11:30am.

The 2021 bonds were bid at 178.65 on Thursday.

Qiagen shares opened in New York at US$50.78 and were trading around US$52.03 after 6pm in London.

Bank of America, Deutsche Bank and Goldman Sachs are global coordinators, and bookrunners with BNP Paribas, HSBC and UniCredit.

Belgian company Mithra Pharmaceuticals raised €125m on Thursday from convertible bonds due 2025, with proceeds partly slated for studies of its hormone and contraceptive treatments.

The new paper came with a 3.5%–4.25% coupon and a premium of 25%–30% to be set over the full-day VWAP. The bonds are callable from January 7 2024 at a 130% trigger. There was a €25m upsize option that was not used.

The company is not rated and so a credit assumption of 600bp was derived from peers and with reference to the risk profile of a late stage biopharma company with three drugs that will soon seek market authorisation. There was no pushback from investors and no borrow facility.

Proceeds will be used to finance a Phase III study of a new generation hormone treatment Donesta and post-authorisation safety study for its Estelle contraceptive, as well as for working capital and financing earn-out obligations in 2021 to former shareholders of Uteron Pharma and funding the pipeline.

Books were covered shortly after 9am in London, and on the full deal including €25m upsize after 12pm with guidance that the deal would price at the wide end with a 4.25% coupon and 25% premium.

With pricing coming at the best end for investors, Mithra opted for €125m. Mithra shares closed at €19.52 on Thursday, having started the year at €26.10 and pushing above €27 in February, while the convert achieved a conversion price of €25.34.

Berenberg was global coordinator, and bookrunner with Belfius Bank/Kepler Cheuvreux.

UK electronics distributor Electrocomponents raised £180m on Thursday in an intraday ABB and PrimaryBid retail offer. 

The proceeds will be used to finance two acquisitions, US company Synovos for US$145m and UK company Needlers for £40m. 

Numis and UBS were bookrunners on the block trade. 

A total of 21.5m shares were sold in the placing at 825p each, representing a 1.2% premium to Wednesday's close of 815.5p. 

A further 300,000 shares were sold through PrimaryBid at the same price. 

Pricing was a 2.9% discount to the middle market price when pricing was agreed. 

It sale equates to about 5% of the company's share capital. 

Existing shareholder Columbia Threadneedle Investments placed a £29.4m order. 

Shares in Electrocomponents rose during the day despite the dilutive share sale, and closed up 3.2% at 841.5p. 

UK software company Aveva Group reported take-up of 99.1% on its fully underwritten £2.835bn rights issue to part-finance its US$5bn acquisition of SoftBank-backed OSIsoft.

The rump of 1.1m was placed in the market on Thursday morning at £32.85 each, more or less flat to Wednesday's close of £32.84.

Rights issue pricing was £22.55, a 32.2% discount to TERP of £33.28, with a total of 125.7m shares on offer on a 7-for-9 basis.

JP Morgan and Numis were global coordinators, with Barclays and BNP Paribas as bookrunners and Santander as lead manager.

Aveva announced its plan to acquire OSIsoft in late August. OSIsoft makes software that captures data from ships, chemical boilers, power plants and other facilities in industries, including oil and gas, mining, pulp and paper, and water.

Shares in Aveva were fairly stable on Thursday, closed down 0.7% at £32.61. 

Danish power cable business NKT on Thursday reported take-up of 99.5% on its DKr1.3bn (US$208m) rights issue. 

The rights issue ran on a 1-for-3 basis at DKr122 per share, a 40% discount to TERP of DKr201.95.

Following a rump placement, all 10.74m were sold. 

Demand for the remaining 0.5% of the offering was extremely high, and almost 200 times oversubscribed. 

The fresh capital will be used to execute a €3bn-plus order book for high-voltage cables, invest in manufacturing and provide flexibility amid Covid-19 uncertainty.

Danske Bank, JP Morgan and Nordea were bookrunners. The capital increase was not underwritten. 

NKT shares ended down 0.6% at DKr250.60 on Thursday. 

Dutch marine survey business Fugro on Thursday reported take-up of 91.9% on its €197m rights issue, launching a rump placing of around €30m after market close. 

The rights issue comprised 92.96m shares on an 11-for-13 basis at €2.12 each, representing a 39.7% discount to TERP of €3.51. 

During the subscription period, Fugro received subscriptions for 85.1m new shares through the exercise of rights, and a further 242,407 shares were subscribed for through a share subscription offering. 

The remaining rump of around 7.5m shares launched on Thursday as an ABB. 

The proceeds are aimed at cutting debt including its 2021 convertible bonds.

The rights issue was underwritten by a syndicate of global coordinators comprising Barclays, ING and Rabobank/Kepler Cheuvreux alongside bookrunners ABN AMRO, BNP Paribas, Credit Suisse and HSBC.

Fugro shares closed up 2.27% on Thursday at €4.05 each. 

South African miner Impala Platinum has bought back 7.4% of its 6.375% 2022 convertible bonds.

In total, Implats bought back R241.46m (US$16m) of the R3.25bn paper that was issued in May 2017 alongside US$250m 3.25% CBs with the same tenor that were bought back last July.

Implats paid a final purchase price of R38,848.78 per R10,000 of bonds, based on the VWAP on the JSE on December 7-9, along with accrued interest of R26.20 per R10,000 of bonds. The initial purchase price was R35.330.33 per R10,000 of principal along with the R26.20 accrued interest.

Implats shares closed at R185.09, versus a conversion price of R48.2315, with the CBs trading on Thursday at R38,634.613.

Morgan Stanley was dealer manager.

Ecofin US Renewables Infrastructure Trust is extending bookbuilding for its up to US$250m London listing as orders have yet to breach the minimum US$150m threshold.

The trust will invest in US renewable energy assets benefiting from support from government incentives and the availability of fixed longer-term revenues contracts of 10-25 years.

The IPO was due to complete on Wednesday and will now extend into next week.

Ecofin said that the response to the IPO from institutional investors and private wealth managers has been positive but it is yet to meet the minimum threshold. An extension will allow a small number of investors further time to complete due diligence.

No new schedule has been set and one will be communicated next week.

A fund managed by Capricorn Investment Group, a long-standing partner of Ecofin, agreed at launch to subscribe for 5% of the shares.

Stifel is sole bookrunner.

JP Morgan Global Core Real Assets is extending bookbuilding for its £80m-plus initial placing, offer for subscription and intermediaries offer.

The fund, which comprises more than 700 real estate assets managed by JP Morgan Asset Management’s US$141bn global alternatives platform, has deployed 99.5% of proceeds from its £148.9m September 2019 IPO.

The trust said that a number of domestic and overseas investors require more time to complete due diligence and the timetable has been extended. A revised timetable will be published in due course.

The deal was due to wrap up this week.

JP Morgan was sole bookrunner.

Downing Renewables & Infrastructure Trust closed at 100.5p in debut trading in London on Thursday versus 100p pricing on its £122.5m IPO.

The stock debuted at 101.5p, with just under 1m shares changing hands, less than 1% of the IPO offering. 

The trust invests in a portfolio of renewable energy and infrastructure assets and the IPO was managed by bookrunner N+1 Singer, with Solid Solutions running an intermediaries offer.

This week’s deals

Monday

Greencoat Renewables (Ireland – Infrastructure fund): €125m placing, 110.6m (18%) new at €1.13 (4.2% discount to €1.18 close, 10.9% premium to €1.019 NAV). Davy, RBC Capital Markets

2MX Organic (France – SPAC): €300m Paris SPAC IPO, 30m (upsized from 25m base) units of one share/warrant, four warrants to subscribe one share at €11.50, 24 months to find acquisition, trading December 9. Deutsche Bank, Societe Generale

Energean (UK - Oil & gas): £42.3m ABB, 6m (3.4%) secondary at 705p (10.2% discount to 785.1p close). Bank of America, Stifel

Tuesday

Inclusio (Belgium – Real estate): €60m primary IPO, 2.8, new at fixed €21.40, €10.5m cornerstones, 62.9% free-float, trading December 10. Bank Degroof Petercam, Belfius Bank/Kepler Cheuvreux

NKT (Denmark – Cables): 99.5% take-up on DKr1.3bn (US$208m) rights issue, 10.74m new on 1-for-3 basis at DKr122 (39.96% discount to TERP of DKr201.95), subscription November 25-December 8, rights trading November 23-December 4, result December 10. Danske Bank, JP Morgan, Nordea

Mailbox REIT (UK): CANCELLED £66m IPO on IPSX Prime in London, shares at 100p, offer for subscription and intermediaries offer closes December 8, result December 11, trading December 14. WH Ireland, Panmure Gordon

SFS Group (Switzerland – Engineering): SFr43.2m (US$48.5m) ABB, 431,890 (1.2%) secondary at SFr100 (4.3% discount to SFr104.50 close). UBS

Ideagen (UK – Software): £48.7m ABB, 22.66m (9.9%) primary at fixed 215p. Canaccord Genuity, finncap

Home24 (Germany – Retail): €46.4m ABB of 2.64m primary shares (10%) at €17.58 (5% discount to Tuesday close). Berenberg

Adevinta (Norway – Online classifieds): NKr1.935bn (US$222m) ABB, 15m (2.2%) secondary at NKr129 (4.65% discount to NKr135.30 close). Arctic Securities, SEB

Thursday

Electrocomponents (UK – Electronics distributor): £180m primary intraday ABB, 21.5m shares at 825p (1.2% premium to Wednesday's close of 815.5p). Numis, UBS

Fugro (Netherlands – Marine survey): 91.9% take-up on €197.1m rights issue, 92.96m new at €2.12, cornerstone commitments for €59.8m (cornerstones also injecting €53.3m at €2.60 per share), 91.9% take-up, 7.5m share rump. Barclays, ING, Rabobank/Kepler Cheuvreux, ABN AMRO, BNP Paribas, Credit Suisse, HSBC

Aveva Group (UK – Software): 99.1% take-up on fully underwritten £2.835bn rights issue, 125.7m shares on a 7-for-9 basis at £22.55 each, (32.2% discount to TERP of £33.28). JP Morgan, Numis, Barclays, BNP Paribas, Santander

Mithra Pharmaceuticals (Belgium): €125m 2025 CB (€25m upsize not exercised), 4.25% coupon (3.5%-4.25%), €25.34 conversion price, 25% premium (25%-30%). Berenberg, Belfius Bank/Kepler Cheuvreux

Qiagen (Netherlands- Biotech services): US$450m-$500m CB due 2027, 100%-102% of principal/redeemed at 100%, 0% to negative 0.28% YTM, 0% coupon, 45%-55% premium set VWAP NYSE December 10-11, pricing December 11. Bank of America, Deutsche Bank, Goldman Sachs, BNP Paribas, HSBC, UniCredit

Acciona (Spain – Renewable energy): €220.5m-€225m ABB, 2.1m (3.8%) secondary at €105-€107. Credit Suisse

Friday

Granges (Sweden – Aluminium): SKr1.7bn (US$198m) rights issue, 28.34m new on 4-for-11 basis at SKr60 (32.2% discount to TERP), 66.4% shareholder commitments, balance underwritten, subscription November 27-December 11, rights trading finishes December 8. Danske Bank, Nordea, Svenska Handelsbanken

Gore Street Energy Storage Fund (UK): £60m initial placing, offer for subscription and intermediaries offer, 60m new shares at 100p (7.8% to the November 27 close of 108.5p, and a 3.6 % premium to the last reported NAV of 96.2p), books November 30-December 11 for placing, offer for subscription and intermediaries offer, result December 14. JP Morgan, Shore Capital

Pipeline

PENDING - JP Morgan Global Core Real Assets (UK)

£80m-plus placing, offer for subscription and intermediaries offer at 100p, closes December 9, result December 10. JP Morgan

PENDING - Ecofin US Renewables Infrastructure Trust (UK)

US$250m LSE IPO, 250m at US$1, closes December 9, result December 10, trading December 14. Stifel

December – Swiss Life REF (CH) Swiss Properties

SFr500m (US$553m) capital raise, max. 4.5m new units on a 2-for-1 basis.

December 14 - N Brown (UK – Online clothing retailer)

£100m placing and open offer, 174.66m in conditional placing, offered in 11-for-18 open offer November 6-December 14, result December 15, EGM November 23. Jefferies (Rothschild advising)

December 14 - Scandinavian Biogas Fuels (Sweden)

SKr532.4m (US$63m) Premier Growth Market Stockholm IPO, 9.33m primary and 4.8m secondary at fixed SKr37.50, 1.4m 10% secondary greenshoe, 46.5%-51.1% free-float, books December 8-14, allocations December 15, trading December 16. ABG Sundal Collier

December 15 - Round Hill Music Royalty Fund

Placing at US$1.01. Closes 3pm December 15, result December 16. Cenkos

December 16 - Bytes Techology Group (UK – Software)

£450m-plus London IPO, 36% new, books c. December 1-16, trading December 17. Numis

December 16 – Schroder BCS Social (UK – Fund)

£100m IPO via placing, offer for subscription and intermediaries offer, 100m at 100p, intermediaries/offer for subscription November 23-December 15, placing closes December 16, result December 17, trading December 22. Winterflood Securities

November/December – Agyapa Royalties (Ghana – Gold)

US$400m-$500m IPO, LSE and Ghanaian Stock Exchange. Bank of America, JP Morgan

November/December – Grammer (Germany – Vehicle parts)

€40m rights issue.

November/December  – Vallourec (France – Steel tubes)

€800m fully underwritten capital increase, approval at EGM April 6. BNP Paribas, Morgan Stanley, Natixis, Societe Generale

November/December   – Keliber (Finland – Lithium mining)

Helsinki IPO. Carnegie, Nordea

November/December – Ibercaja (Spain – Bank)

IPO required before end 2020. JP Morgan, Morgan Stanley, Bank of America, UBS 

November/December – Giochi Preziosi (Italy – Toys)

IPO. Banca Akros, Banca IMI, Barclays, Jefferies, Santander (Rothschild advising)

January 2021 - InDex Pharmaceuticals (Sweden)

SKr500m rights issue, January EGM, terms to follow. Barclays, Carnegie

January 2021 - Swiss Steel

€200m-equivalent rights issue, December 22 EGM, guaranteed by main shareholder

February 2021 – VH Global Sustainable Energy Opportunities (UK)

£400m London IPO, prospectus early January, completion February. Numis

March 2021 – ITAB Shop Concept (Sweden – Retail solutions)

SKr768m (US$91m) rights issue, 102.38m on 1-for-1 basis at SKr7.50 (24% discount to SKr9.91 TERP), 94% guaranteed, EGM January 15, subscription mid-February. Macquarie Capital, Nordea

H1 2021  –  Sasol (South Africa - Chemicals)

US$2bn rights issue. Bank of America, Citigroup, JP Morgan
